name: market for wheat grain | wheat grain | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/28178/documentation

This is a market activity. Each market represents the consumption mix of a product in a given geography, connecting suppliers with consumers of the same product in the same geographical area. Markets group the producers and also the imports of the product (if relevant) within the same geographical area. They also account for transport to the consumer and for the losses during that process, when relevant.;This is the market for 'wheat grain', in the geography of Victoria state in Australia.;This dataset represents the transport of 1 kg of wheat grain from the farm to the corresponding market, i.e. whole wheat processing facility (dry mill) . No losses are considered in this dataset.;The product 'wheat grain' is a grain. It is an annual crop. The ecoinvent database also contains this product from organic and Swiss integrated production.

The activity starts at the gate of wheat grain cultivation farm.

This activity ends with the supply of 'wheat grain', to the consumers of this product. Transport is included. Product losses during transportation are assumed negligible and are therefore not included.
category: A:Agriculture, forestry and fishing/01:Crop and animal production, hunting and related service activities/011:Growing of non-perennial crops/0111:Growing of cereals (except rice), leguminous crops and oil seeds

processDocumentation.timeDescription: The time period is the same as the in transforming activity for the same reference product.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Data represent the situation in Victoria state in Australia.

exchanges.description: The crops are transported by lorry (20%) and train (80%) in a total distance of 273km in the Victoria state in Australia. Transport distances based on Eady, S. (2017). Greenhouse gas emissions from the cultivation of canola oilseed in Australia, CSIRO: Clayton, Australia. With road rail mix inferred from Commonwealth of Australia (2009). Road and rail freight: competitor or complements. Information sheet 34, Australian Government, Bureau of Infrastructure, Transport and Regional Economics.
